title: Rear Brake Caliper - Removal

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Do not allow a brake component to hang unsupported on the brake hose or line.
Brake hoses or lines that are not supported may become damaged or bent.
Bent or damaged brake hoses or lines lead to reduced braking efficiency causing loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Notice - Do not spill brake fluid
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Spilled brake fluid will damage paintwork.
Make sure no damage is made to the brake pad material when moving the brake pads.
Allowing the brake pads to come into contact with each other or sharp objects may cause the material to crack or break.
Damage to the brake pads may result in reduced braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Remove the caliper mounting bolts and slide the caliper off the brake disc.
During Installation the master cylinder will require back bleeding.
Therefore make sure the brake caliper is detached and the pistons pushed out as described in

Using a suitable a flat metal plate approximately 2 mm thick and 30 to 50 mm wide (for example a gasket scraper) between the brake pads, pump the rear brake pedal until the plate is held by the brake pads.
The bleed screw is fitted to the rear brake hose union.
Make a note of the rear brake hose orientation in relationship to the caliper for installation.
Disconnect the brake hose at the caliper and place the free end of the hose in a suitable container to collect the brake fluid.
Collect the spacer and discard the three sealing washers.
